H0.text: Ionic compounds are solids with high melting and boiling points.

H1.text: Magnetic compounds are solids with high melting and boiling points.

H2.text: Superheated compounds are solids with high melting and boiling points.

H3.text: Metal alloys are solids with high melting and boiling points.

A4.text: Inorganic compounds with simple ions typically have small ions, and thus have high melting points, so are solids at room temperature.

A5.text: Some substances with larger ions, however, have a melting point below or near room temperature (often defined as up to 100 °C), and are termed ionic liquids.

A6.text: Hafnium carbonitride (HfCN) is a refractory compound with the highest known melting point of any substance to date and the only one confirmed to have a melting point above 4,273 K (4,000 °C; 7,232 °F) at ambient pressure.

A7.text: The melting point of a pure substance is always higher and has a smaller range than the melting point of an impure substance or, more generally, of mixtures.

A8.text: In general, compounds with ionic bonds have high normal boiling points, if they do not decompose before reaching such high temperatures.

A9.text: The higher a compound's normal boiling point, the less volatile that compound is overall, and conversely, the lower a compound's normal boiling point, the more volatile that compound is overall.
